URL-encoded JSON array of message attachments, a legacy method for rich content. See Slack API documentation for structure.
Example: "%5B%7B%22fallback%22%3A%20%22Required%20plain-text%20summary%20of%20the%20attachment.%22%2C%20%22color%22%3A%20%22%2336a64f%22%2C%20%22pretext%22%3A%20%22Optional%20text%20that%20appears%20above%20the%20attachment%20block%22%2C%20%22author_name%22%3A%20%22Bobby%20Tables%22%2C%20%22title%22%3A%20%22Slack%20API%20Documentation%22%2C%20%22title_link%22%3A%20%22https%3A%2F%2Fapi.slack.com%2F%22%2C%20%22text%22%3A%20%22Optional%20text%20that%20appears%20within%20the%20attachment%22%7D%5D"

unfurl_links.description: Enable unfurling of text-based URLs. Defaults `false` for bots, `true` if `as_user` is `true`.

unfurl_media.description: Disable unfurling of media content from URLs if `false`. Defaults to `true`.

markdown_text.description:
PREFERRED: Write your message in markdown for nicely formatted display. Supports: headers (# ## ###), bold (**text** or __text__), italic (*text* or _text_), strikethrough (~~text~~), inline code (`code`), code blocks (```), links ([text](url)), block quotes (>), lists (- item, 1. item), dividers (--- or ***), context blocks (:::context with images), and section buttons (:::section-button). IMPORTANT: Use 
 for line breaks (e.g., 'Line 1
Line 2'), not actual newlines. USER MENTIONS: To tag users, use their user ID with <@USER_ID> format (e.g., <@U1234567890>), not username. 
Examples:
  "# Status Update

System is **running smoothly** with *excellent* performance.

```bash
kubectl get pods
```

> All services operational ✅"
  "## Daily Report

- **Deployments**: 5 successful
- *Issues*: 0 critical
- ~~Maintenance~~: **Completed**

---

**Next**: Monitor for 24h"

reply_broadcast.description: If `true` for a threaded reply, also posts to main channel. Defaults to `false`.

tools.name: SLACK_SENDS_EPHEMERAL_MESSAGES_TO_CHANNEL_USERS
tools.title: Send an ephemeral message
tools.description: DEPRECATED: Sends an ephemeral message to a user in a channel. Use `send_ephemeral_message` instead.

text.description:
How this field works and whether it is required depends on other fields you use in your API call. See below for more detail.
Example: "Hello world"

user.description:
User ID of the user to send the ephemeral message to.
Example: "U0BPQUNTA"

parse.description:
Change how messages are treated. Defaults to none. See below.
Example: "full"

blocks.description:
A JSON-based array of structured blocks, presented as a URL-encoded string.
Example: "[{\"type\": \"section\", \"text\": {\"type\": \"plain_text\", \"text\": \"Hello world\"}}]"

as_user.description:
Pass true to post the message as the authed user, instead of as a bot. Defaults to false. See authorship below.
Example: true

channel.description:
Channel, private group, or DM channel to send message to. Can be an encoded ID, or a name.
Example: "C1234567890"

icon_url.description:
URL to an image to use as the icon for this message. Must be used in conjunction with as_user set to false, otherwise ignored. See authorship below.
Example: "http://lorempixel.com/48/48"

username.description:
Set your bot's user name. Must be used in conjunction with as_user set to false, otherwise ignored. See authorship below.
Example: "My Bot"

thread_ts.description:
Provide another message's ts value to make this message a reply. Avoid using a reply's ts value; use its parent instead.
Example: "1234567890.123456"

icon_emoji.description:
Emoji to use as the icon for this message. Overrides icon_url. Must be used in conjunction with as_user set to false, otherwise ignored. See authorship below.
Example: ":chart_with_upwards_trend:"

link_names.description:
Find and link channel names and usernames.
Example: true

attachments.description:
A JSON-based array of structured attachments, presented as a URL-encoded string.
Example: "[{\"pretext\": \"pre-hello\", \"text\": \"text-world\"}]"

tools.name: SLACK_SET_A_CONVERSATION_S_PURPOSE
tools.title: Set a conversation's purpose
tools.description: Sets the purpose (a short description of its topic/goal, displayed in the header) for a Slack conversation; the calling user must be a member.

channel.description:
The ID of the conversation (channel, direct message, or group message) to set the purpose for.
Examples:
  "C012AB3CD4E"
  "D0G9ALE3P"
  "G12345678"

purpose.description:
The new purpose for the conversation. This text will be displayed as the channel description. The maximum length is 250 characters.
Examples:
  "Discuss project milestones and deadlines."
  "Team updates and daily stand-ups."

tools.name: SLACK_SET_DND_DURATION
tools.title: Set DND duration
tools.description: Turns on Do Not Disturb mode for the current user, or changes its duration.

num_minutes.description:
Number of minutes, from now, to snooze until.
Example: "60"

tools.name: SLACK_SET_PROFILE_PHOTO
tools.title: Set profile photo
tools.description: This method allows the user to set their profile image.

image.description: File contents via a POST var called image.

crop_x.description: X coordinate of top-left corner of crop box

crop_y.description: Y coordinate of top-left corner of crop box

tools.name: SLACK_SET_READ_CURSOR_IN_A_CONVERSATION
tools.title: Set conversation read cursor
tools.description: Marks a message, specified by its timestamp (`ts`), as the most recently read for the authenticated user in the given `channel`, provided the user is a member of the channel and the message exists within it.

ts.description:
The timestamp of the message to mark as the most recently read. This is typically a Unix timestamp with microsecond precision (e.g., '1625800000.000200').
Examples:
  "1678886400.000100"
  "1702982400.123456"

channel.description:
The ID of the public channel, private channel, or direct message to set the read cursor for.
Examples:
  "C012QRSTUW9"
  "G012ABCDEFG"
  "D012HIJKLMN"

tools.name: SLACK_SET_SLACK_USER_PROFILE_INFORMATION
tools.title: Set Slack user profile information
tools.description: Updates a Slack user's profile, setting either individual fields or multiple fields via a JSON object.

name.description:
Name of a single profile field to set. Use with `value` if `profile` is not provided.
Examples:
  "first_name"
  "status_text"
  "custom_field_id_X123"

user.description:
ID of the user whose profile will be updated; defaults to authenticated user. Team admins on paid teams can specify another member's ID.
Example: "U012A3CDE"

value.description:
Value for the single profile field specified by `name`. Use with `name` if `profile` is not provided.
Examples:
  "John Doe"
  "On a call"
  "New custom value"

profile.description:
URL-encoded JSON string of key-value pairs for profile fields to update (max 50 fields, 255 chars per field name). If provided, `name` and `value` are ignored.
Example: "%7B%22first_name%22%3A%22Alice%22%2C%20%22last_name%22%3A%22Wonderland%22%2C%20%22status_text%22%3A%22Exploring%22%2C%20%22status_emoji%22%3A%22%3Arabbit%3A%22%7D"

tools.name: SLACK_SET_STATUS
tools.title: Set Slack Status
tools.description: Sets the Slack status for the authenticated user with a custom text and optional emoji. The status appears next to the user's name in Slack.

status_text.description:
The status text to set (e.g., 'In a meeting', 'Out for lunch', 'Working remotely'). Maximum 100 characters.
Examples:
  "In a meeting"
  "AFK"
  "Out for lunch"
  "Focusing 🎯"

status_emoji.description:
Optional emoji to display with the status (e.g., ':coffee:', ':calendar:', ':house:'). Must be in :emoji_name: format.
Examples:
  ":coffee:"
  ":calendar:"
  ":house:"
  ":computer:"

status_expiration.description:
Optional Unix timestamp (in seconds) when the status should expire and be automatically cleared. If not provided, status persists until manually cleared.
Examples:
  1640995200
  1672531200

tools.name: SLACK_SET_THE_TOPIC_OF_A_CONVERSATION
tools.title: Set conversation topic
tools.description: Sets or updates the topic for a specified Slack conversation.

topic.description:
The new topic for the conversation. It must be a string up to 250 characters long. Text formatting and linkification are not supported.
Examples:
  "Q4 Planning Discussion"
  "Weekly Sync Updates"

channel.description:
The ID of the public channel, private channel, direct message, or multi-person direct message conversation for which the topic will be set.
Examples:
  "C1234567890"
  "G0123456789"
  "D012345678"

tools.name: SLACK_SET_USER_PROFILE_PHOTO_WITH_CROPPING_OPTIONS
tools.title: Set the user's profile image
tools.description: DEPRECATED: This method allows the user to set their profile image. Use `set_profile_photo` instead.

image.description: File contents via a POST var called image.

crop_x.description: X coordinate of top-left corner of crop box

crop_y.description: Y coordinate of top-left corner of crop box

tools.name: SLACK_SHARE_A_ME_MESSAGE_IN_A_CHANNEL
tools.title: Share a me message in a channel

annotations.title: Share a me message in a channel

tools.description: Sends a 'me message' (e.g., '/me is typing') to a Slack channel, where it's displayed as a third-person user action; messages are plain text and the channel must exist and be accessible.

text.description:
Content of the 'me message', displayed as an action performed by the user (e.g., if text is 'is feeling happy', it appears as '*User is feeling happy*').
Examples:
  "is preparing for a meeting."
  "updated the project status."
  "needs coffee."

channel.description:
Specifies the target channel by its public ID (e.g., 'C1234567890'), private group ID, IM channel ID, or name (e.g., '#general', '@username').
Examples:
  "C1234567890"
  "#random"
  "D012345678"

tools.name: SLACK_SHARE_REMOTE_FILE_IN_CHANNELS
tools.title: Share a remote file in channels

annotations.title: Share a remote file in channels

tools.description: Shares a remote file, which must already be registered with Slack, into specified Slack channels or direct message conversations.

file.description:
The unique ID of the remote file registered with Slack. Either this `file` field or the `external_id` field (or both) is required to identify the file.
Example: "F0123456789"

channels.description:
A comma-separated list of channel IDs where the remote file will be shared. These can include public channel IDs, private channel IDs, or direct message channel IDs.
Examples:
  "C0123456789,D0987654321"
  "C061MP4F097"

external_id.description:
The globally unique identifier (GUID) for the remote file, as provided by the app that registered it with Slack. Either this `external_id` field or the `file` field (or both) is required to identify the file.
Examples:
  "myapp-unique-file-id-007"
  "external-doc-id-54321"

tools.name: SLACK_START_CALL
tools.title: Start call
tools.description: Registers a new call in Slack using `calls.add` for third-party call integration; `created_by` is required if not using a user-specific token.

title.description:
The name or title for the call. This will be displayed in Slack to identify the call.
Examples:
  "Project Alpha Sync"
  "Q3 Planning Session"

users.description:
A JSON string representing an array of user objects to be registered as participants in the call. Each user object in the array should define a participant using their `slack_id` (Slack User ID) and/or an `external_id` (an identifier from the third-party application, unique to that user within that application). For instance: `'''[{"slack_id": "U012A3BCD4E"}, {"external_id": "user-xyz@example.com", "slack_id": "U012A3BCD4F"}]'''`.
Examples:
  "'''[{\"slack_id\": \"U012A3BCD4E\"}, {\"external_id\": \"participant1@example.com\", \"slack_id\": \"U012A3BCD4F\"}]'''"
  "'''[{\"slack_id\": \"W012A3CDE\"}]'''"
  "'''[{\"external_id\": \"meeting-user-789\"}]'''"

join_url.description:
The URL required for a client to join the call (e.g., a web join link). This field is mandatory.
Examples:
  "https://thirdparty.call/join/meeting123"
  "https://example.com/s/abc-123-def"

created_by.description:
Slack user ID of the creator; optional (defaults to authenticated user) if using a user token, otherwise required.
Examples:
  "U012A3BCD4E"
  "U061F7AUR"

date_start.description:
The start time of the call, specified as a UTC UNIX timestamp in seconds. For example, `1678886400` corresponds to March 15, 2023, at 12:00 PM UTC.
Examples:
  "1678886400"
  "1700000000"

external_unique_id.description:
A unique identifier for the call, supplied by the third-party call provider. This ID must be unique across all calls from that specific service. This field is required.
Examples:
  "v=abcdef123456"
  "call-ext-98765uuid-from-provider"

external_display_id.description:
An optional, human-readable identifier for the call, supplied by the third-party call provider. If provided, this ID will be displayed in the Slack call object interface.
Examples:
  "Meeting H.323"
  "CONF-7890"

desktop_app_join_url.description:
An optional URL that, when provided, allows Slack clients to attempt to directly launch the third-party call application. This is typically a deep link URI for the specific application.
Examples:
  "your-app-protocol://call/12345"
  "zoomus://zoom.us/join?confno=1234567890"

tools.name: SLACK_START_REAL_TIME_MESSAGING_SESSION
tools.title: Start real time messaging session
tools.description: Initiates a Slack RTM session providing a single-use WebSocket URL (valid 30s) for event streaming; does not set initial presence status.

presence_sub.description:
Delivers presence events only for explicitly subscribed users if `True`. See Slack's [presence subscriptions](https://slack.dev) documentation.
Examples:
  true
  false

batch_presence_aware.description:
Enables batching of presence status deliveries for subscribed users if `True`, altering `presence_change` event structure. See Slack's [batch presence](https://slack.dev) documentation.
Examples:
  true
  false

tools.name: SLACK_UNARCHIVE_A_PUBLIC_OR_PRIVATE_CHANNEL
tools.title: Unarchive a public or private channel

annotations.title: Unarchive a public or private channel

tools.description: Unarchives a specified public or private Slack channel that is currently archived, using its channel ID.

channel_id.description:
The unique identifier of the public or private channel to be unarchived.
Examples:
  "C0123456789"
  "G0987654321"

tools.name: SLACK_UNARCHIVE_CHANNEL
tools.title: Unarchive channel
tools.description: Reverses conversation archival.

channel.description:
ID of conversation to unarchive
Example: "C1234567890"

tools.name: SLACK_UNPIN_ITEM_FROM_CHANNEL
tools.title: Unpin message from channel
tools.description: Unpins a message, identified by its timestamp, from a specified channel if the message is currently pinned there; this operation is destructive.

channel.description:
The ID of the channel where the message is pinned (e.g., a public channel, private channel, or direct message).
Examples:
  "C1234567890"
  "G0987654321"

timestamp.description:
Timestamp of the message to unpin. This is required to identify the specific message to be removed from the channel's pinned items.
Examples:
  "1625640000.000100"
  "1700000000.123456"

tools.name: SLACK_UPDATE_AN_EXISTING_SLACK_USER_GROUP
tools.title: Update Slack user group
tools.description: Updates an existing Slack User Group, which must be specified by an existing `usergroup` ID, with new optional details such as its name, description, handle, or default channels.

name.description:
New name for the User Group. Must be unique among User Groups.
Example: "Q4 Marketing"

handle.description:
New mention handle. Must be unique among channels, users, and User Groups.
Example: "marketing-team-alpha"

channels.description:
Comma-separated encoded channel IDs to set as default channels.
Example: "C1234567890,C2345678901"

usergroup.description:
Encoded ID of the existing User Group to update.
Example: "S0615G0KT"

description.description:
New short description for the User Group.
Example: "Team responsible for Q4 marketing campaigns."

include_count.description:
If true, include the number of users in the User Group in the response.
Examples:
  true
  false

tools.name: SLACK_UPDATES_AN_EXISTING_REMOTE_FILE
tools.title: Update an existing remote file
tools.description: Updates metadata or content details for an existing remote file in Slack; this action cannot upload new files or change the fundamental file type.

file.description:
Slack's unique identifier for the remote file (e.g., `F12345678`). Used to identify the file if `external_id` is not provided. One of `file` or `external_id` is required to specify the file to update.
Examples:
  "F0123ABC456"
  "F7890XYZ123"

title.description:
New title for the remote file. If omitted, the current title remains unchanged.
Examples:
  "Updated Project Proposal Q3"
  "Final Presentation Draft"

token.description: Authentication token for authorizing the API request to Slack.

filetype.description:
New filetype for the remote file. This typically describes the kind of file, e.g., `pdf`, `gdoc`, `image`, `text`. See Slack API documentation for specific supported `filetype` values. Providing an inaccurate filetype might affect how the file is handled or displayed.
Examples:
  "pdf"
  "jpg"
  "gdoc"
  "sketch"
  "txt"
  "mp4"
  "zip"

external_id.description:
Creator-defined Globally Unique Identifier (GUID) for the remote file. Used to identify the file if `file` ID is not provided. One of `file` or `external_id` is required to specify the file to update.
Examples:
  "item_12345_report_2024"
  "guid-doc-xyz-final"

external_url.description:
New publicly accessible URL for the remote file. If provided, this updates the link associated with the file in Slack.
Examples:
  "https://example.com/updated_document.pdf"
  "https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/new_sheet_id_v2"

preview_image.description: A string that references the new preview image for the document. The referenced image data will be sent as `multipart/form-data`. This could be a local file path (if supported by the client), a public URL, or base64 encoded image data. Max 1MB. Updates the file's preview in Slack.

indexable_file_contents.description: Plain text content extracted from the remote file, used by Slack to improve searchability. This can be a summary or the full text. Maximum 1MB. If provided, updates the searchable content.

tools.name: SLACK_UPDATES_A_SLACK_MESSAGE
tools.title: Update a Slack message
tools.description: Updates a Slack message, identified by `channel` ID and `ts` timestamp, by modifying its `text`, `attachments`, or `blocks`; provide at least one content field, noting `attachments`/`blocks` are replaced if included (`[]` clears them).

ts.description:
Timestamp of the message to update (string, Unix time with microseconds, e.g., `'1234567890.123456'`).
Example: "1625247600.000200"

text.description:
This sends raw text only, use markdown_text field for formatting. New message text (plain or mrkdwn). Not required if `blocks` or `attachments` are provided. See Slack formatting rules.
Examples:
  "Hello world, this is an *updated* message."
  "Check out this link: <https://example.com>"

parse.description:
Parse mode for `text`: `'full'` (mrkdwn) or `'none'` (literal). If not provided, defaults to `'client'` behavior, overriding original message's `parse` setting.
Examples:
  "full"
  "none"
  "client"

blocks.description:
**DEPRECATED**: Use `markdown_text` field instead. URL-encoded JSON array of layout blocks. Replaces existing blocks if field is provided; use `[]` (empty array string) to clear. Omit field to leave blocks untouched. Required if `text` and `attachments` are absent. See Slack API for format.
Examples:
  "[{\"type\": \"section\", \"text\": {\"type\": \"mrkdwn\", \"text\": \"This is an updated section block.\"}}]"
  "[]"

as_user.description:
Set to `'true'` to update as the authenticated user (bots are considered such). Defaults to app/bot identity.
Example: "true"

channel.description:
The ID of the channel containing the message to be updated.
Examples:
  "C1234567890"
  "G0abcdefh"

link_names.description:
Set to `'true'` to link channel/user names in `text`. If not provided, Slack's default update behavior may override original message's linking settings.
Example: "true"

attachments.description:
URL-encoded JSON array of attachments. Replaces existing attachments if field is provided; use `[]` (empty array string) to clear. Omit field to leave attachments untouched. Required if `text` and `blocks` are absent. See Slack API for format.
Examples:
  "[{\"fallback\": \"Plain-text summary of attachment.\", \"color\": \"#2eb886\", \"text\": \"Optional text that appears within the attachment\"}]"
  "[]"

markdown_text.description:
**PREFERRED**: Write your updated message in markdown for nicely formatted display. Supports headers (#), bold (**text**), italic (*text*), strikethrough (~~text~~), code (```), links ([text](url)), quotes (>), and dividers (---). Your message will be posted with beautiful formatting.
Examples:
  "# Updated Status

The issue has been **resolved** and systems are *fully operational*.

```bash
# All services running
kubectl get services
```"
  "## Progress Update

- **Phase 1**: ✅ Complete
- *Phase 2*: In progress (80%)
- ~~Phase 3~~: **Started early**

---

**ETA**: Tomorrow"

tools.name: SLACK_UPDATE_SLACK_CALL_INFORMATION
tools.title: Update call information
tools.description: Updates the title, join URL, or desktop app join URL for an existing Slack call identified by its ID.

id.description:
Unique identifier of the call to update, obtained when a call is created (e.g., via `calls.add` Slack API method).
Examples:
  "R0123ABCDEF"
  "R9876ZYXWVU"

title.description:
New title for the call.
Examples:
  "Project Alpha Review"
  "Q3 Planning Session"

join_url.description:
New URL for clients to join the call.
Examples:
  "https://example.com/join/meeting/12345"
  "https://another-service.com/call/abc987"

desktop_app_join_url.description:
URL to directly launch the third-party call application from Slack clients.
Examples:
  "your-app-protocol://join?call_id=12345"
  "slack://call?id=abcdefg"

tools.name: SLACK_UPDATE_USER_GROUP_MEMBERS
tools.title: Update user group members
tools.description: Replaces all members of an existing Slack User Group with a new list of valid user IDs.

users.description:
Comma-separated string of encoded user IDs for the new, complete member list, replacing all existing members. User IDs typically start with 'U' or 'W'.
Example: "U012AB34CD,W567EF89GH,U01234567"

usergroup.description:
The encoded ID of the User Group whose members are to be updated. This ID typically starts with 'S'.
Example: "S012AB34CD"

include_count.description:
If true, the response `usergroup` object includes `user_count` and potentially `channel_count` fields, reflecting counts after the update.
Examples:
  "true"
  "false"

tools.name: SLACK_UPLOAD_OR_CREATE_A_FILE_IN_SLACK
tools.title: Upload or create a file in Slack

annotations.title: Upload or create a file in Slack

tools.description: Uploads a file to Slack, requiring either `content` (for text) or `file` (for binary data), optionally sharing it in specified `channels` or as a reply via `thread_ts`.

file.description: Binary file content as multipart/form-data; use for non-text files. Omit if `content` is used. Provide actual file content, not a path.

title.description:
Title of the file, displayed in Slack.
Examples:
  "My Document"
  "Team Meeting Notes Q3"

content.description:
Text content of the file; use for text-based files. Omit if `file` is used.
Example: "This is the content of my text file."

channels.description:
Comma-separated channel names or IDs for sharing; if omitted, file is private to the uploader.
Examples:
  "C1234567890,marketing-updates"
  "general"

filename.description:
Filename to be displayed in Slack.
Examples:
  "report.pdf"
  "image.png"

filetype.description:
Slack file type (e.g., 'text', 'pdf'); Slack auto-detects if omitted. Refer to Slack API for full list.
Examples:
  "text"
  "pdf"
  "auto"
  "python"

thread_ts.description:
Timestamp of a parent message to upload this file as a reply; use the original message's `ts`.
Example: 1678886400

initial_comment.description:
Optional message to introduce the file in specified `channels`.
Examples:
  "Here is the Q3 financial report."
  "Check out this design mockup."
